nodes.name: DocumentToText
nodes.description: The DocumentToText node extracts text content from documents, including PDF, TXT, DOCX, and image files, located in a specified file path or directory. It processes either a single file or an entire directory, producing a structured DataFrame with columns for the extracted text, file name, page numbers, and optionally, base64-encoded data for PDFs and images.

nodes.name: SQL
nodes.description: This node runs the given SQL on the incoming DataFrame
nodes.details:
SQL Details


SQL node receives an input data frame. It creates a temporary table on top of that data frame. It executes the provided SQL in the node on the temporary table.

The resulting data frame of running the SQL is passed on to the next node.
nodes.examples:
SQL Examples


Below are some examples of SQL.

Temporary table name used : tempTable

The schema of the Input Dataframe is : id, price, lotsize, bedrooms, bathrms, stories, driveway, recroom, fullbase, gashw, airco, garagepl, prefarea

find the average price of houses


select avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable


find bedrooms with avg price greater than 10000


select bedrooms, avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable group by bedrooms) as temp where avg_price > 10000


details of houses with bedrooms avg price greater than 10000


select tempTable.* , inner_table.avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg_price from
(select bedrooms, avg(price) as avg_price from tempTable group by bedrooms) as temp where avg_price > 10000) as inner_table
JOIN tempTable ON(inner_table.bedrooms = tempTable.bedrooms)
nodes.hint: Whenever the table is changed, go to InferSchema tab and Infer the Schema

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: tempTable
fields.title: Temp Table
fields.description: Temp Table Name to be used

fields.name: sql
fields.value:
SELECT 
  directorypath,
  fileName,
  concat_ws('\n', collect_list(content)) as concatenated_content
FROM fire_temp_table
WHERE content IS NOT NULL
GROUP BY directorypath, fileName

fields.description: SQL to be run

nodes.name: Concat Columns
nodes.description: This node creates a new DataFrame by concatenating the specified columns of the input DataFrame
nodes.details:
Concat Columns Node Details


It adds a new column to the dataframe created by concatenating multiple columns and separated by the specified separator.

Input

  • COLUMNS :- Select columns that need to be concatenated. Multiple columns can be selected for concatenation.
  • CONCATENATED COLUMN NAME :- Enter name of the column to list the concatenated values in the outgoing Dataframe.
  • SEPARATOR :- Enter a Separator value to separate values from different columns in the output. It can be a multi-character value. Common Separator values used are as follows:
b. *
c. -
d. :
e. [Blank Space]

Output

  • New concatenated column would be added to the Outgoing Dataframe listing the concatenated values.
nodes.examples:
Concat Columns Examples


Incoming Dataframe


In this example we have considered an Incoming Dataframe with following rows:

CUST_CD | CUST_NAME | AGE | DATE_OF_JOINING | SALARY
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
C01 | MATT | 50 | 12-02-2002 | USD 200000.00
C02 | LISA | 45 | 15-11-2020 | GBP 100000.00
C03 | ROBIN | 30 | 10-10-2015 | EUR 15000.00
C04 | MARCUS | 35 | 01-01-2021 | AUD 350000.00

Concat Columns Node Configuration and Output


Concat Columns Node is configured to concatenate two columns [CUST_CD] and [CUST_NAME] from the incoming Dataframe into a new column [CUST_IDENTIFIER] using separator [-].
Output Dataframe would be created as below:

CUST_CD | CUST_NAME | AGE | DATE_OF_JOINING | SALARY | CUST_IDENTIFIER
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
C01 | MATT | 50 | 12-02-2002 | USD 200000.00 | C01-MATT
C02 | LISA | 45 | 15-11-2020 | GBP 100000.00 | C02-LISA
C03 | ROBIN | 30 | 10-10-2015 | EUR 15000.00 | C03-ROBIN
C04 | MARCUS | 35 | 01-01-2021 | AUD 350000.00 | C04-MARCUS

fields.title: Columns
fields.description: Columns to be concatenated

fields.title: Concatenated Column Name
fields.description: Column name for the concatenated columns

fields.name: sep
fields.title: Separator
fields.description: Separator to be used when concatenating the columns

nodes.name: Drop Columns
nodes.description: This node creates a new DataFrame by dropping the specified columns
nodes.details:
Drop Columns Node Details


This node creates a new DataFrame by dropping the selected columns.

It drops the selected columns from the outgoing dataframe.

Columns that need to be dropped are to be selected in the 'Selected' list. Multiple columns can be selected in the list that needs to be dropped.
nodes.examples:
Drop Columns Node Examples


Incoming Dataframe


In this example we have considered an Incoming Dataframe having following columns:

  • CUST_CD
  • CUST_NAME
  • DOB
  • ADDRESS

Drop Columns Node Configuration And Output


[DOB] and [ADDRESS] columns are selected to be dropped from the outgoing Dataframe.
Outgoing dataframe would contain only below two columns after dropping the selected columns:

  • DOB
  • ADDRESS

fields.description: The columns to be excluded from the output DataFrame

nodes.name: Case When
nodes.description: This node creates a new Dataframe with a new column appended to it containing value based on the condition met
nodes.details:
Case When Node Details


This node creates a new Dataframe with new output column added to the incoming dataframe. Value of the new column is set based on the Condition met and corresponding value fetched.

It evaluates a set of expressions and outputs value of the expression that evaluates to true. If none of the expressions evaluates to true then it outputs value assigned in the 'else' section.

When conditions can be entered as followings:


Using Comparison Operators

  • Comparing a value against a String column -> Example: PRD_CATEGORY = 'MACHINE'
  • Checking for not equal to condition against a String column -> Example: PRD_CATEGORY != 'MACHINE'
  • Comparing a value against a Numeric column -> Example: AGE >= 35
  • Using a Mathematical operator -> Example: (AGE * 10) < 90
  • Checking for multiple values using IN and NOT IN -> Example: DEPT IN ('HR', 'SALES')

Using Logical Operators To Combine Multiple Expressions

  • Checking for two conditions in single expression -> Example: DEPT = 'HR' AND AGE >= 25
  • Checking for two conditions in single expression -> Example: AGE >= 35 OR AGE <45

Checking For Null Value

  • Checking whether a column value is Null -> Example: DEPT IS NULL

Checking For Blank Value

  • Checking whether value in a column is empty -> Example: TRIM(DATE_OF_JOINING) = ''

Checking Against Boolean Value

  • Checking whether a Boolean column is True or False -> Example: IS_DATEGREATER = TRUE

Checking Against Date-Time Value

  • Comparing a Date column against a Date value -> Example: CURR_DATE > TO_DATE('2021-12-12','yyyy-MM-dd')
  • Comparing a Date-Time column against a Date-Time value -> Example: CURR_TIME > TO_TIMESTAMP('2021-12-12 12:12:12','yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss')

Values can entered as followings:


Assigning value from a column

  • Assigning value from a column[DEPT] to output (Value) -> Example: DEPT
  • Applying a operator before assigning value from a column -> Example: SALARY * 10

Assigning a String or Number constant

  • Assigning a String constant -> Example: 'DEPT IS HR'
  • Assigning a Number constant -> Example: 1000

Assigning Current Date and Current Timestamp

  • Assigning Current Date -> Example: CURRENT_DATE
  • Assigning Current Date-Time -> Example: CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
nodes.examples:
Case When Node Examples


Incoming Dataframe


In this example we have considered a Incoming Dataframe with following rows:

EMP_CD | EMP_NAME | DEPT | AGE | DATE_OF_JOINING | PERFORMANCE | SALARY
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
E01 | DAVID | HR | 25 | 2021-01-01 | GOOD | 12000
E02 | JOHN | SALES | 35 | 2019-05-04 | VERY GOOD | 11000
E03 | MARTIN | MARKETING | 40 | 2018-06-07 | AVERAGE | 34000
E04 | TONY | MARKETING | 45 | 2017-02-01 | VERY VERY GOOD | 12500
E05 | MARK | HR | 25 | 2020-12-21 | BAD | 78999

CaseWhen Node Configuration


CaseWhen node is configured as below to compute values for the output column:

WHEN CONDITION | VALUE
------------------------------------------------------------------
SALARY < 12500 | 'FIRST_GRADE'
SALARY>= 12500 AND SALARY < 30000 | 'SECOND_GRADE'
SALARY >- 30000 AND SALARY < 70000 | 'THIRD_GRADE'
ELSE | 'FOURTH_GRADE'

[ELSE] is the default condition processed if no other condition is met

Node Output


Output Dataframe would be created as below where value of [SALARY] is compared against [WHEN CONDITION] and [VALUE] is fetched for the output column [SALARY_GRADE]:

EMP_CD | EMP_NAME | DEPT | AGE | DATE_OF_JOINING | PERFORMANCE | SALARY | SALARY_GRADE
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
E01 | DAVID | HR | 25 | 2021-01-01 | GOOD | 12000 | FIRST_GRADE
E02 | JOHN | SALES | 35 | 2019-05-04 | VERY GOOD | 11000 | FIRST_GRADE
E03 | MARTIN | MARKETING | 40 | 2018-06-07 | AVERAGE | 34000 | THIRD_GRADE
E04 | TONY | MARKETING | 45 | 2017-02-01 | VERY VERY GOOD | 12500 | SECOND_GRADE
E05 | MARK | HR | 25 | 2020-12-21 | BAD | 78999 | FOURTH_GRADE

Values can also be assigned based on the value of another column


if CaseWhen node is configured as below to compute values for the output column:

WHEN CONDITION | VALUE
------------------------------------------------------------------
SALARY IS NULL | AGE
ELSE | SALARY

nodes.name: Multi LLM Query
nodes.description: The Multi LLM Query node is designed to query multiple large language models (LLMs) from providers such as OpenAI, Bedrock, and Gemini, using a DataFrame as input. It processes user queries, text content, and/or base64-encoded images to generate responses based on the selected model and task, producing a structured DataFrame output.

fields.name: task

fields.description: Specify the task to perform: summary, translation, topic extraction, or other.

optionsMap.translation: Translate the following content to default language
optionsMap.topic_extraction: Extract key topics from the following content.

fields.name: customPrompt
fields.value:
First Document: ${destinationPath1}\nLanguage:${selectLanguage}\n
Second Document: ${destinationPath2}\nLanguage:${selectLanguage1}

Please check whether the 2nd document is following all the rules and guideline of what the 1st document have.

Whatever the the languages are, you have to translate them into English and do the below things
Make a good title
1. generate a concise summary based on the below points (short and crisp) in 250 words.
2. Output must be in tabular format, Percentage must be in numbers, Calculate the overall percentage similarity between the first document and the second document. The output table should contain below columns
Section,	Identical Lines,	Paraphrased Lines,	New Lines,	Similarity Percentage
3. Identify the lines in the first document that are identical to lines in the seconddocument. Identify the lines in the first document that are paraphrased versions of lines in the second document.(Section wise similarity) It should have below columnsÂ 
Section,	Identical Lines,	Paraphrased Lines,	New Lines,	Similarity Percentage
4. Identify the lines in the first document that are entirely new or not present in the second document. Calculate the similarity percentage for each section of the document (e.g., Scope, Purpose, Compliance and Reporting Obligations, etc.). (Identical lines) It should have below columns
First Document Line,	Second Document Line
5. Identify any sections that are exactly the same as the first document. Identify any specific key phrases or terms from the second document that are missing in the first document. (Para phrased lines) It should have below columns
First Document Line,	Second Document Line
6. Identify any new phrases or terms introduced in the first document that are not in the second document. Determine if any sections or subsections have been added, removed, or restructured in the first document compared to the second. (New Lines in first document and Key Phrases or Terms Missing in First Document )
Provide concise and to-the-point answers in proper HTML format and proper HTML table format. Do not use ** to bold (use <strong> tag to bold). And the table should have proper border for row and column


All the headings and sub headings should be bold and blue in color. Use intag styling and use strong tag for bold.

nodes.name: Print N Rows
nodes.description: Prints the specified number of records in the DataFrame. It is useful for seeing intermediate output
nodes.details:
Print N Rows Node Details


This node is used to print the first N rows from the incoming dataframe.

The Number of rows that needs to be printed can be configured in the node.

Input Parameters

  • OUTPUT STORAGE LEVEL : Keep this as DEFAULT.
  • TITLE : Enter a short description for the type of information being displayed.
  • NUM ROWS TO PRINT : Set an integer value(N) which controls the number of rows to be displayed(Default N=10).
  • DISPLAY DATA TYPE : Shows the output dataframe column datatypes by default.

Output

  • This node can be used to view, analyze and validate the output of the Dataframe.
nodes.examples:
when input 5 in no of rows,it will show first 5 rows of the table as follows

PartID SupplierID PartName

P9271 S798 Part_D
P523 S955 Part_K
P3201 S332 Part_M
P9634 S527 Part_G
P9345 S850 Part_M

fields.name: comment
fields.value:
1. Read both the PDF document
  2. Extract the text from both of them
  3. Send them to LLM with the respective Languages, mentioned in the promt
  4. Then take a comparison report among those two pdfs
